results.title: Gwen Harwood
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A charming film of poet Gwen Harwood speaking at her home in Tasmania about her work in poetry and her love for music and opera.

results.title: Money, class and power [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Philip Smith, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Australia: beyond the fatal shore [Widescreen]”.
Art critic Robert Hughes reflects on his relationship to Australia, 35 years after leaving the country. Contemplative after his near fatal car accident, Hughes reflects fondly on his childhood in Australia with an appreciation that only came from questioning his mortality. Episode three questions the illusion that Australia is a classless society. During the program Hughes goes to that great leveller of classes - the races - with former Prime Minister Bob Hawke, visits Werribee Park, a mansion founded on the success of sheep, and speaks to the creators and first residents of the resort community Sanctuary Lakes. He goes to the opera with Melbourne establishment figure Lady Susan Renouf and visits the home of nouveau riche Jeannie Pratt. The concepts of mateship, good luck and gambling are touched on, as is the power wielded by media magnates Kerry Packer and Rupert Murdoch. Hughes also visits the “underclass” of Sydney and makes the journey over to Perth which witnessed a boom in wealth and real estate in the 1980s and saw the rise and fall of Alan Bond.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Philip Smith, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, BBC and Oxford Film and Television

results.title: A Visual dictionary
results.creator_credit: Sheldon Renan, David Adams and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Film Terms”.
Illustrates basic filmmaking language as it is used in the writing, shooting, and editing of a motion picture. Defines and demonstrates script terminology, kinds of shots, lenses and their effects, camera angles and movement, sound, and optical effects. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary/teacher levels.

results.title: Schizophrenia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Barriers of the Mind”.
The introduction of major psychotic drugs have meant that many schizophrenics can now lead normal lives in the community. These drugs however, can have severe side effects, and sometimes they can only limit the disease. This program looks at some typical case studies in schizophrenia and seeks out opinions on the use of drugs and other methods of treatment of this most frightening illness.

results.title: Body and soul [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Richard Curson Smith, ABC-TV (Australia), BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Australia: beyond the fatal shore [Widescreen]”.
Art critic Robert Hughes reflects on his relationship to Australia, 35 years after leaving the country. Contemplative after his near fatal car accident, Hughes reflects fondly on his childhood in Australia with an appreciation that only came from questioning his mortality. Episode one explores the concept of the pleasure seeking Aussie and whether there is more to us than our pursuit of leisure. Sydney’s annual Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras proves a focal point for the program which looks at beach culture, surf culture, the evolution of the wowser and the larrikin, censorship and homoeroticism in sport. Features interviews with Roy and H.G. (John Doyle and Greig Pickhaver), Dare Jennings and Bill Leeke. Includes footage of Norman Lindsay’s residence in the Blue Mountains, surf beaches on the East Coast, Old Sydney Town and an X-rated film shoot. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

results.title: Depression
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Barriers of the Mind”.
We all suffer low spirits occasionally, but when depression becomes a devastating illness it can be life threatening. This program looks at the way manic depressives cope with their illness, its causes and at the type of treatment which is available to them.

results.title: Judith Wright
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
As well as being one of Australia’s more eminent poets and novelists, Judith Wright is an outspoken commentator on conservation and Aboriginal land rights.

results.title: Bad girls. Series two. Discs 3 & 4 [DVD]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Bad girls. Series two”.
The Leaving: (wri. Jayne Hollinson, dir. Mike Adams): Shell’s back on enhanced and is targetting Barbara. Dominic and Zandra are drawn closer through her illness. Denny and Crystal get a new roommate in the young Shaz. “Family plan” (wri. Phil Ford, dir. Mike Adams): Shaz explains to Denny the circumstances of her triple murder charge. Barbara confesses to the attack on Shell. Julie’s trying to have another baby and someone from Yvonne’s past is the latest addtion to the ward. Babes behind bars go under. “Rough justice” (wri. Ann McManus, dir. Mike Adams): Renee’s got it in for everyone and dies under mysterious circumstances. Sylvia is reprimanded over an incident involving Denny and Shaz. Fenner’s having family troubles. “Facing up” (wri. Maureen Chadwick, dir. Laurence Moody): Jim’s mind isn’t on the job, to the detriment of his fellow officers. Nikki’s jealous of Helen and Dominic, Helen has a plan to make Shaz realise the consequence of her actions. “Oh what a night” (wri. Maureen Chadwick, Ann McManus, dir. Laurence Moody): Nikki will do anything to spend one night with Helen on the eve of a party to celebrate Sylvia’s 30 years in the service. Crystal leaves Lark Hall.
